prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: CO 2-1 and SiO 5-4 are simultaneously observable over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s), but that requires two spectral tunings (with overlapping spws). The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution. There is no data rate issue with these TDM observations.

From our ALMA data so far we can constrain the total extent of the ejecta to be about 0.3x0.7 arcsec, so we only need to recover angular sizes up to that. Within that zone, models predict chemical stratification and clumpy structure on size scales of 0.1", so must resolve those.

CO 2-1 and SiO 5-4 are simultaneously observable over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s), but that requires two spectral tunings. The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution.
We used our Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 total flux densities of the ejecta (marginally resolved in those data), and Cycle 0 non-LTE excitation modeling, to predict the average surface brightnesses of the lines to be ~3K. The ejecta is expected to be clumpy, but achieve a high fidelity understanding of the structure requires imaging at S/N>~10 even if the ejecta were to turn out to be more smooth than expected.
For the continuum, we used the Cycle 0 measured total flux density in Band 6 of 20mJy, divided by the proposed beam size and accounting for the fact that the emission at these frequencies is mostly in the ~1arcsec radius annular shocked ring.

CO 2-1 and SiO 5-4 are simultaneously observable over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s), but that requires two spectral tunings (with overlapping spws). The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution. There is no data rate issue with these TDM observations.

From our ALMA data so far we can constrain the total extent of the ejecta to be about 0.3x0.7 arcsec, so we only need to recover angular sizes up to that. Within that zone, models predict chemical stratification and clumpy structure on size scales of 0.1", so must resolve those.

The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). The ejecta is expected to be clumpy, but achieve a high fidelity understanding of the structure requires imaging at S/N>~10 even if the ejecta were to turn out to be more smooth than expected.
For the continuum, we used the Cycle 0 measured total flux density in Band 6 of 20mJy, divided by the proposed beam size and accounting for the fact that the emission at these frequencies is mostly in the ~1arcsec radius annular shocked ring.

CO 4-3 must be observed over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s). We use 4 overlapping spws in two SGs. The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution. There is no data rate issue with these TDM observations.

From our ALMA data so far we can constrain the total extent of the ejecta to be about 0.3x0.7 arcsec, so we only need to recover angular sizes up to that. Within that zone, models predict chemical stratification and clumpy structure on size scales of 0.1", so must resolve those.

CO 2-1 and SiO 5-4 are simultaneously observable over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s), but that requires two spectral tunings. The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution.
We used our Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 total flux densities of the ejecta (marginally resolved in those data), and Cycle 0 non-LTE excitation modeling, to predict the average surface brightnesses of the lines to be ~3K. The ejecta is expected to be clumpy, but achieve a high fidelity understanding of the structure requires imaging at S/N>~10 even if the ejecta were to turn out to be more smooth than expected.
For the continuum, we used the Cycle 0 measured total flux density in Band 7 of 20mJy, and 40mJy in B9, divided by the proposed beam size and accounting for the fact that the emission at these frequencies is mostly in the 0.4x0.7" central ejecta.

CO 4-3 must be observed over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s). We use 4 overlapping spws in two SGs. The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution. There is no data rate issue with these TDM observations.

From our ALMA data so far we can constrain the total extent of the ejecta to be about 0.3x0.7 arcsec, so we only need to recover angular sizes up to that. Within that zone, models predict chemical stratification and clumpy structure on size scales of 0.1", so must resolve those.

The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For the continuum, we used the Cycle 0 measured total flux density in Band 7 of 20mJy, and 40mJy in B9, divided by the proposed beam size and accounting for the fact that the emission at these frequencies is mostly in the 0.4x0.7" central ejecta.

SiO 6-5 must be observed over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s). We use two overlapping spws. The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution. There is no data rate issue with these TDM observations.

From our ALMA data so far we can constrain the total extent of the ejecta to be about 0.3x0.7 arcsec, so we only need to recover angular sizes up to that. Within that zone, models predict chemical stratification and clumpy structure on size scales of 0.1", so must resolve those.

CO 2-1 and SiO 5-4 are simultaneously observable over the full-width to zero-intensity of the SN ejecta (+/-2000 km/s), but that requires two spectral tunings. The spectral resolution required is tied to the spatial resoltion because the ejecta is freely expanding with r=vt (t=28yrs in 2015). For angular resolution of dr=0.1"=7e16cm, mapping the same size scale along the line of sight requires dv=300km/s spectral resolution.
We used our Cycle 0 and Cycle 2 total flux densities of the ejecta (marginally resolved in those data), and Cycle 0 non-LTE excitation modeling, to predict the average surface brightnesses of the lines to be ~3K. The ejecta is expected to be clumpy, but achieve a high fidelity understanding of the structure requires imaging at S/N>~10 even if the ejecta were to turn out to be more smooth than expected.
For the continuum, we used the Cycle 0 measured total flux density in Band 6 of 20mJy, divided by the proposed beam size and accounting for the fact that the emission at these frequencies is mostly in the ~1arcsec radius annular shocked ring.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
SN1987A is the closest, best studied supernova in the modern era. Our team has demonstrated the revolutionary results that ALMA can provide by observing SN1987A.
Instabilities during and immediately after the explosion lead to heterogeneous mixing of the chemically stratified stellar interior. After a short time, free expansion dominates, and the structure is frozen in. Recent models show blobs ~10^17cm=0.13arcsec in size today, and that the structure depends critically on explosion details such as asymmetry in the explosion and magnetic field.
We propose to create 3-d maps of SiO and CO emission and excitation (from multiple transitions) at <0.1", the first direct observation of the explosion-mixed structure.
These data will also provide important constraints on supernova ejecta chemistry, dust formation, and composition, when we compare SiO and SO to the high-resolution distribution of dust continuum.
They will also reveal detailed particle acceleration physics: by mapping the spectral index of nonthermal emission, we will understand local magnetic field amplification, real-time synchrotron losses, and perhaps even find the mysteriously elusive pulsar wind nebula.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00748.S PI Matsuura: spectral survey of molecular content -- lower angular resolution, very complementary and distinct science
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00280 PI Matsuura, Molecules in supernova 1987A - chemistry, nucleosynthesis and gas dynamics - partially observed, chemical analysis in progress. 2013.1.00063 PI Indebetouw, Resolving SN1987A: a detailed look at a unique laboratory of shock, dust, molecular, and nuclear physics- not yet observed, complementary to this proposal. 2012.1.00075 PI Indebetouw , SN1987A: A Unique Laboratory of Shock, Molecular and Dust Physics- only partially observed so far 2012.1.00273 PI Indebetouw, SN87A: A Unique Laboratory for Shock and Dust Physics - 3 papers and Astronomy Magazine's "#1 Space Story of 2014"
